part1.converted_description:
You are given a configuration of stacks of crates and a series of rearrangement steps. Each step involves moving a quantity of crates from one stack to another. The crates are moved one at a time, and the order of the crates is preserved when moved. After the rearrangement process is complete, determine which crate ends up on top of each stack. For example:

```
    [D]    
[N] [C]    
[Z] [M] [P]
 1   2   3

move 1 from 2 to 1
move 3 from 1 to 3
move 2 from 2 to 1
move 1 from 1 to 2

```

In this example, there are three stacks of crates. Stack 1 contains two crates: crate `Z` is on the bottom, and crate `N` is on top. Stack 2 contains three crates; from bottom to top, they are crates `M`, `C`, and `D`. Finally, stack 3 contains a single crate, `P`.

Then, the rearrangement procedure is given. In each step of the procedure, a quantity of crates is moved from one stack to a different stack. In the first step of the above rearrangement procedure, one crate is moved from stack 2 to stack 1, resulting in this configuration:

```
[D]        
[N] [C]    
[Z] [M] [P]
 1   2   3

```

In the second step, three crates are moved from stack 1 to stack 3. Crates are moved *one at a time*, so the first crate to be moved (`D`) ends up below the second and third crates:

```
        [Z]
        [N]
    [C] [D]
    [M] [P]
 1   2   3

```

Then, both crates are moved from stack 2 to stack 1. Again, because crates are moved *one at a time*, crate `C` ends up below crate `M`:

```
        [Z]
        [N]
[M]     [D]
[C]     [P]
 1   2   3

```

Finally, one crate is moved from stack 1 to stack 2:

```
        [Z]
        [N]
        [D]
[C] [M] [P]
 1   2   3

```

You just need to know *which crate will end up on top of each stack*; in this example, the top crates are `C` in stack 1, `M` in stack 2, and `Z` in stack 3, so you should combine these together and return the message `*CMZ*`.

*After the rearrangement procedure completes, what crate ends up on top of each stack?*

Input Format:
The input consists of a series of lines representing the initial configuration of the stacks of crates (a crate is represented by `[<letter>]`, the absents of a crate is three whitespaces, all crates are whitespace seperated), followed by a series of lines representing the rearrangement steps. Each line contains a stack number (integer) and a crate letter (uppercase character) separated by a space. The stacks are numbered starting from 1.

part2.converted_description:
You are given the same scenario as Part 1, but now the crane-mover has the ability to pick up and move multiple crates at once. When multiple crates are moved from one stack to another, the order of the crates is preserved. Determine which crate ends up on top of each stack after the rearrangement process is complete.

Input Format:
The input is the same as in Part 1.

input:
[M]             [Z]     [V]    
    [Z]     [P]     [L]     [Z] [J]
[S] [D]     [W]     [W]     [H] [Q]
[P] [V] [N] [D]     [P]     [C] [V]
[H] [B] [J] [V] [B] [M]     [N] [P]
[V] [F] [L] [Z] [C] [S] [P] [S] [G]
[F] [J] [M] [G] [R] [R] [H] [R] [L]
[G] [G] [G] [N] [V] [V] [T] [Q] [F]
